comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Whoopee! I have been wondering what this place might have looked like . . . It is the old Benevolent Asylum at the corner of Pitt and Devonshire Streets at Railway Square, in what was then referred to as Redfern. Next to the OLD Redfern railway terminus. We are looking east with the old cemeteries behind and the Standard Brewery on Elizabeth Street. This fine building was demolished in 1901 to make way for the new Central Station. 1895 interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=0... View to the right of the station - www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/2654873676/

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: Well done beachcomber! I am sure many family historians would love seeing what this building look like.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 1821 it was built - Imagine somebody trying to knock that down nowadays! Governor Macquarie was closely involved in this building - www.bensoc.org.au/director/aboutus/benevolentsocietyhisto... . The Benevolent Society has been involved in magnificent work over nearly 200 years - www.bensoc.org.au/director/aboutus/benevolentsocietyhisto...

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] So true. We have some info on the Benevolent Society in our collection - recently highlighted in the Lachalan Macquarie Gallery. Now we can add this image too :-D
